paragraphs.text:
%md

## Analyzing Telemetry

By default, Apache Metron (incubating) will archive the enriched telemetry in HDFS. This includes the telemetry produced by the default sensor suite, including Bro, Yaf, and Snort.  This makes it simple to use a variety of tools to analyze your telemetry and gain new insights.  This notebook will walk you through the process of working with the archived Bro telemetry created by Metron using Zeppelin and Spark.

result.msg:
Analyzing Telemetry

By default, Apache Metron (incubating) will archive the enriched telemetry in HDFS. This includes the telemetry produced by the default sensor suite, including Bro, Yaf, and Snort. This makes it simple to use a variety of tools to analyze your telemetry and gain new insights. This notebook will walk you through the process of working with the archived Bro telemetry created by Metron using Zeppelin and Spark.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### What telemetry is available?


The fully parsed, enriched, and triaged telemetry for each the sensors is available in HDFS.  If none appears to be available in your environment, allow Metron to run a little longer before continuing in this notebook. Now let's check and see what Bro telemetry is available in HDFS.

result.msg:
What telemetry is available?

The fully parsed, enriched, and triaged telemetry for each the sensors is available in HDFS. If none appears to be available in your environment, allow Metron to run a little longer before continuing in this notebook. Now let's check and see what Bro telemetry is available in HDFS.

paragraphs.text:
%sh

hdfs dfs -ls -C -R /apps/metron/indexing/indexed/bro

result.msg:
/apps/metron/indexing/indexed/bro/enrichment-null-0-0-1484847868551.json
/apps/metron/indexing/indexed/bro/enrichment-null-0-0-1484848728527.json

paragraphs.text:
%md
### How do I load the telemetry?

The archived telemetry is simply the raw JSON produced by Metron.  This makes it very simple to parse and analyze with a variety of tools.  Let's take a look at the telemetry that we received from Bro.

result.msg:
How do I load the telemetry?

The archived telemetry is simply the raw JSON produced by Metron. This makes it very simple to parse and analyze with a variety of tools. Let's take a look at the telemetry that we received from Bro.

paragraphs.text:
%md

###

Loading this data with Spark SQL could not be simpler.

result.msg: Loading this data with Spark SQL could not be simpler.

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

create temporary table bro
  using org.apache.spark.sql.json
  options (path "hdfs:///apps/metron/indexing/indexed/bro")

%spark.sql

select count(*) as count from bro

result.msg:
count
7000

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

sqlContext.table("bro").printSchema()

result.msg:

paragraphs.text:
%md 
###How do I analyze the telemetry?

Spark SQL makes it simple to use basic SQL to analyze the data. Zeppelin provides a rich, customizable mechanism for visualizing the data.

result.msg:
How do I analyze the telemetry?

Spark SQL makes it simple to use basic SQL to analyze the data. Zeppelin provides a rich, customizable mechanism for visualizing the data.

paragraphs.text:
%md

###

Bro produces data about a number of different network protocols.  Let's see which types of protocols exist in our data.

result.msg: Bro produces data about a number of different network protocols. Let's see which types of protocols exist in our data.

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

select protocol, count(*) as count
from bro
group by protocol

result.msg:
protocol	count
http	5387
dns	1613

paragraphs.text:
%md 

###

Let's take a look at when the Bro telemetry was receieved.  Are there any odd gaps?  Are there fluctuating periods of high and low activity?

If there is not enough data for this visualization to be interesting, let Metron consume a bit more data before continuing.

result.msg:
Let's take a look at when the Bro telemetry was receieved. Are there any odd gaps? Are there fluctuating periods of high and low activity?

If there is not enough data for this visualization to be interesting, let Metron consume a bit more data before continuing.

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

select 
  from_unixtime(timestamp/1000,'YYYY-MM-dd HH:00') as time, 
  protocol,
  count(*) as count
from bro 
group by FROM_UNIXTIME(timestamp/1000,'YYYY-MM-dd HH:00'), protocol
order by time asc

%md

###

Which are the most active HTTP hosts?

result.msg: Which are the most active HTTP hosts?

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

select count(*) as count,
    concat(`enrichments.geo.ip_dst_addr.country`, "/", `enrichments.geo.ip_dst_addr.city`) as location,
    host
from bro
where protocol = 'http'
group by host, 
    concat(`enrichments.geo.ip_dst_addr.country`, "/", `enrichments.geo.ip_dst_addr.city`)
order by count desc

result.msg:
count	location	host
1840	null	7oqnsnzwwnm6zb7y.gigapaysun.com
1380	null	node1
864	FR/Strassbourg	62.75.195.236
484	US/Los Angeles	comarksecurity.com
408	US/Phoenix	runlove.us
108	FR/Strassbourg	ubb67.3c147o.u806a4.w07d919.o5f.f1.b80w.r0faf9.e8mfzdgrf7g0.groupprograms.in
107	FR/Strassbourg	va872g.g90e1h.b8.642b63u.j985a2.v33e.37.pa269cc.e8mfzdgrf7g0.groupprograms.in
106	null	ip-addr.es
90	FR/Strassbourg	r03afd2.c3008e.xc07r.b0f.a39.h7f0fa5eu.vb8fbl.e8mfzdgrf7g0.groupprograms.in

paragraphs.text:
%md

###

Are there any web servers running on non-standard ports?

For our purposes, let's consider anything other than port 80 as non-standard.

result.msg:
Are there any web servers running on non-standard ports?

For our purposes, let's consider anything other than port 80 as non-standard.

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

select protocol,
    concat(ip_src_addr, ":", ip_src_port) as client, 
    concat(ip_dst_addr, ":", ip_dst_port) as server, 
    count(*) as requests
from bro  
where protocol in ("http","https") 
    and ip_dst_port <> "80"
group by protocol,
    concat(ip_src_addr, ":", ip_src_port), 
    concat(ip_dst_addr, ":", ip_dst_port)

result.msg:
protocol	client	server	requests
http	192.168.66.1:50451	192.168.66.121:8080	1380

paragraphs.text:
%md

###

Are there any DNS servers running on non-standard ports?

For our purposes, let's consider anything other than port 53 as non-standard.

result.msg:
Are there any DNS servers running on non-standard ports?

For our purposes, let's consider anything other than port 53 as non-standard.

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

select protocol,
    concat(ip_src_addr, ":", ip_src_port) as client, 
    concat(ip_dst_addr, ":", ip_dst_port) as server, 
    count(*) as requests
from bro  
where protocol = "dns"
    and ip_dst_port <> "53"
group by protocol,
    concat(ip_src_addr, ":", ip_src_port), 
    concat(ip_dst_addr, ":", ip_dst_port)

result.msg:
protocol	client	server	requests
dns	192.168.66.1:5353	224.0.0.251:5353	651

paragraphs.text:
%md

###

Are there any mime types that we should be concerned with?

result.msg: Are there any mime types that we should be concerned with?

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

mimes = sqlContext.sql("select *, explode(resp_mime_types) as mime from bro where resp_mime_types is not null")
mimes.registerTempTable("mimes")

%md

###

Each HTTP record can contain multiple mime types.  These have to be 'exploded' so that we can work with them properly.

result.msg: Each HTTP record can contain multiple mime types. These have to be 'exploded' so that we can work with them properly.

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

select mime, count(*) as count 
from mimes 
group by mime
order by count desc

result.msg:
mime	count
image/png	1415
text/html	815
text/plain	472
application/x-dosexec	112
application/x-shockwave-flash	108
image/x-icon	98

paragraphs.text:
%md

###

The `application/x-dosexec` looks interesting.  Where did that originate?

result.msg: The application/x-dosexec looks interesting. Where did that originate?

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

select protocol,
    from_unixtime(timestamp/1000,'YYYY-MM-dd HH:mm') as time,
    ip_src_addr,
    ip_dst_addr,
    `enrichments.geo.ip_dst_addr.city` as city,
    `enrichments.geo.ip_dst_addr.country` as country
from mimes 
where mime = 'application/x-dosexec'

%md

###

The requests themselves look very suspicious.

result.msg: The requests themselves look very suspicious.

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

select host, uri, count(*) as count
from bro 
where ip_dst_addr = '62.75.195.236'
group by host, uri
order by count desc

%md

###

When are the interactions with the suspicious host occuring?

result.msg: When are the interactions with the suspicious host occuring?

paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

select 
    from_unixtime(timestamp/1000,'YYYY-MM-dd HH:mm') as time,
    count(*) as count
from bro
where ip_dst_addr = '62.75.195.236'
group by from_unixtime(timestamp/1000,'YYYY-MM-dd HH:mm')

%md

### Next Steps

Through this brief analysis we have uncovered something that looks suspicious.  So far we have leveraged only the geo-enriched Bro telemetry.  From here, we can start to explore other sources of telemetry to better understand the scope and overall exposure. Continue to investigate our suspicions with the other sources of telemetry available in Metron.   
 * Try loading the Snort data and see if any alerts were triggered.  
 * Load the flow telemetry and see what other internal assets have been exposed to this suspicious actor.  
 * If an internal asset has been compromised, investigate the compromised asset's activity to uncover signs of internal reconnaissance or lateral movement.

result.msg:
Next Steps

Through this brief analysis we have uncovered something that looks suspicious. So far we have leveraged only the geo-enriched Bro telemetry. From here, we can start to explore other sources of telemetry to better understand the scope and overall exposure. Continue to investigate our suspicions with the other sources of telemetry available in Metron.

  • Try loading the Snort data and see if any alerts were triggered.
  • Load the flow telemetry and see what other internal assets have been exposed to this suspicious actor.
  • If an internal asset has been compromised, investigate the compromised asset's activity to uncover signs of internal reconnaissance or lateral movement.
